guideline: WCAG 3.3.3 Error Suggestion, 3.3.1 Error Identification, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
best_practice: Invalid email. Please enter a valid address like name@example.com.
explanation: Error messages must not only identify an issue (3.3.1) but also suggest how to correct it (3.3.3). Linking messages via aria-describedby ensures assistive tech conveys them (4.1.2).

guideline: WCAG 3.3.3 Error Suggestion, 3.3.1 Error Identification
failure_example: Passwords do not match
best_practice: Passwords do not match. Please ensure both fields contain the same value.
explanation: Errors should be clearly identified (3.3.1) and announced automatically (4.1.3). Suggestions guide users toward correction (3.3.3).

guideline: WCAG 3.3.3 Error Suggestion, 3.3.1 Error Identification, 1.3.1 Info and Relationships
best_practice: Invalid date. Please enter in DD/MM/YYYY format, e.g., 23/08/1990.
explanation: Suggesting a correction (3.3.3) requires first identifying the problem (3.3.1) and maintaining semantic linkage between field and message (1.3.1).

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification
failure_example: This field is required.
best_practice: This field is required.
explanation: Error messages should be visible when relevant, not hidden via CSS.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification
best_practice: You must accept the terms to proceed.
explanation: Required checkboxes must provide clear error messages when left unchecked.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification
best_practice: Please enter a valid email address.
explanation: Email fields must display error messages when input is invalid.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification
best_practice: Invalid email. Please use format: user@example.com
explanation: Providing an ARIA relationship ensures screen readers announce errors properly.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions
failure_example: <input type='text' name='username' id='username' placeholder='Enter your username'>
best_practice: <label for='username'>Username:</label><input type='text' name='username' id='username' required>
explanation: Placeholders should not be the only indicator of a fieldâ€™s purpose. Labels must be present and programmatically associated.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions
failure_example: <input type='radio' name='gender' value='male'> Male <input type='radio' name='gender' value='female'> Female
best_practice: <fieldset><legend>Select your gender:</legend><input type='radio' name='gender' value='male'> Male <input type='radio' name='gender' value='female'> Female</fieldset>
explanation: Radio button groups should use a <fieldset> and <legend> for accessibility.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.3 Error Suggestion
best_practice: Invalid input. Please enter in YYYY-MM-DD format.
explanation: Error messages should provide suggestions for correction, not just indicate failure.

best_practice: <label for='username'>Username:</label><input type='text' name='username' id='username'>
explanation: A missing label makes input fields inaccessible to screen readers. A placeholder alone is not sufficient, as it disappears when users type.

guideline: WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions
failure_example: <input type='email' name='email' id='email' placeholder='Enter your email'>
best_practice: <label for='email'>Email:</label><input type='email' name='email' id='email' placeholder='e.g., user@example.com'>
explanation: Placeholders should not be the only indicator of a field's purpose, as they disappear on focus. Labels must be present and programmatically associated.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions
best_practice: Must be at least 8 characters long.
explanation: If an input has specific constraints (e.g., length, pattern), users should be informed before submission. Providing upfront instructions prevents unnecessary errors and improves accessibility.

guideline: WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
best_practice: <label for='name'>Name:</label><input type='text' id='name'>
explanation: Labels must be associated with the correct input using 'for' attributes that match the input ID.

guideline: WCAG 2.4.6 Headings and Labels, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
best_practice: <button>Submit</button>
explanation: Interactive elements must have accessible names to be understandable by assistive technologies.

guideline: WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
explanation: Required fields should be indicated visually and programmatically with 'required' or 'aria-required='true''.

guideline: WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
explanation: If a field is required, it must be indicated both visually (with a symbol or text) and programmatically (using 'required' and/or 'aria-required').

guideline: WCAG 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions
explanation: Required fields must have clear labels or instructions indicating what information is expected. Relying only on the required attribute without context fails WCAG 3.3.2.

guideline: WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
explanation: Visual indicators for required fields must also be communicated programmatically to assistive technologies. Using 'display:none' hides important information from screen reader users.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification
best_practice: Invalid email format
explanation: Error messages must be programmatically linked via 'aria-describedby' so screen readers announce them.

guideline: WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Relationships
failure_example: <input type='radio' name='contact' value='email'> Email <input type='radio' name='contact' value='phone'> Phone
best_practice: <fieldset><legend>Preferred Contact Method</legend><input type='radio' name='contact' value='email'> Email <input type='radio' name='contact' value='phone'> Phone</fieldset>
explanation: Grouping related fields with <fieldset> and <legend> improves clarity for screen reader users.

guideline: WCAG 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
best_practice: <input type='text' value='12345' readonly aria-readonly='true'>
explanation: Programmatic attributes like 'readonly' should be reinforced with ARIA attributes for accessibility.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions, 1.3.1 Info and Relationships
explanation: Required fields must not rely on color alone. Provide both visual and programmatic indicators (required attribute or aria-required) so assistive technologies announce the requirement.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification, 1.4.1 Use of Color
best_practice: Please enter a valid email address.
explanation: Errors must not be indicated by color alone. Programmatic cues like aria-invalid and text messages linked with aria-describedby help users and assistive technologies identify and correct the issue.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification, 3.3.3 Error Suggestion
best_practice: Please enter your date of birth in the format YYYY-MM-DD.
explanation: Error messages should be clear and provide guidance for correction. Ambiguous or generic errors like 'Invalid input' fail to help users recover from mistakes.

field_type: text input with missing error association
guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
best_practice: Invalid ZIP code. Please use 5 digits.
explanation: Error messages must be programmatically linked to inputs using aria-describedby so that screen readers announce the error in context.

guideline: WCAG 3.3.1 Error Identification, 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions, ACT Rule: Error Identification
best_practice: Must be at least 8 characters long.
explanation: Required fields indicated only by color or symbols fail WCAG. Instructions must be available in text and programmatically associated, ensuring screen readers convey the requirement.

field_type: required field indicated by color only
guideline: WCAG 1.4.1 Use of Color, 3.3.2 Labels or Instructions
explanation: Using color alone (red label) to indicate a required field fails WCAG 1.4.1. A non-color cue such as a visible asterisk and programmatic attributes (required or aria-required) must be included.

field_type: error state indicated by color only
guideline: WCAG 1.4.1 Use of Color, 3.3.1 Error Identification
failure_example: <label for='email'>Email</label><input id='email' type='email' style='border:2px solid red;'>
best_practice: Enter a valid email address, e.g., user@example.com
explanation: Error states indicated only by red borders or red text fail WCAG 1.4.1. Errors must include a clear text description and programmatic cues such as aria-invalid and aria-describedby.

guideline: WCAG 1.4.1 Use of Color, 3.3.1 Error Identification, 3.3.3 Error Suggestion, 4.1.2 Name Role Value
failure_example: <label for='email'>Email</label><input id='email' type='email' style='border:2px solid red;'>
best_practice: Please enter a valid email address in the format name@example.com.
explanation: Using only red color to indicate an error fails 1.4.1. A visible, text-based error message (3.3.1) combined with a clear correction suggestion (3.3.3) and programmatic linkage (4.1.2) ensures the issue is perceivable and actionable by all users.
